newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian reforms will lead to NATO - president.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian reforms will lead to NATO - president.

text.p: Bulgarian President Petar Stoyanov said on Monday Bulgaria expected no miracles from the Madrid summit but was firmly on a path that would eventually lead to integration in NATO.
"We are not expecting miracles and we all know why," said Stoyanov in a national address on the eve of his departure for the summit.

"While the current star pupils of the former Eastern Bloc chose the right way without a doubt, we spent years dithering in front of Europe's gates. Today we are making up lost time with a 'Bulgarian storm.'"
The summit which opens on Tuesday is expected to invite the former Warsaw Pact states of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to join the Western alliance.
Stoyanov said he would remind the summit of his country's strategic position, its good relations with its neighbours and its role as a factor for Balkan stability.
"Our intentions for European and Euro-Atlantic integration are very serious and the first obstacle will not stop us," he said. "NATO's southern flank is not complete without Bulgaria."
The Socialist government, ousted from power by month-long street protests in January and February, had been ambivalent on NATO membership for fear of upsetting its traditional allies in Moscow.
The interim cabinet in February made a clear statement of Bulgaria's desire to join NATO, and the reformist government which took office in May reaffirmed this aim.
"Bulgaria's aspiration to join NATO is not a fashionable infatuation but a strategic aim," said Stoyanov, who is due to meet U.S. President Bill Clinton on Tuesday afternoon.

"The North Atlantic Treaty for us means not only reforms in the army, but democracy, a developed economy, a standard of living, free journalists, motivated young people and most of all a way of life which has been chosen on the eve of the 21st century."
